This patch fixes loading of meta-models (extent) including referenced meta-models (referencedExtents). It also implements name-based lookup for both the main extent and all of the referencedExtents. This is an updated patch that addresses getElementsByType() as well.
It also does an extent.unload() within the dispose() method and dispose() is called by the finalize() method. This code needs testing against this issue: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/atl_discussion/message/976
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.
Latest patch gives trouble with meta-classes that can "alternatingly contain" eachother, causing a StackOverflowError in ASMEMFModel.addReferencedExtentsFor().

Created an attachment (id=40954) Updated patch that prevents StackOverflowError in ASMEMFModel.addReferencedExtentsFor()
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

External superclasses of meta-classes are not found. Example: UML2 imports Ecore, but the only reference is to EModelElement via a superclass relationship. The ASMEMFModel.addReferencedExtentsFor() method should also go through superclasses in addition to references.

I committed the last version of this patch (2006-05-10 11:43) on CVS. This will allow other "CVS users" to test it and I hope to provide some feedbacks.
Thanks for your contribution Dennis.

bug.short_desc: MDR4ATL from CVS does not support fully qualified meta-class names

long_desc.thetext:
Created an attachment (id=41444) Patch for fully qualified meta-class names
This patch allows the use of fully qualified meta-class names, separated by '::'. The behaviour should be the same as in EMF4ATL.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

The proposed patch (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=41444) does not solve the entire problem. MDR meta-models are serialised in XMI 1.2, which means that XML tags start with <namespace>:<meta-class>. The namespace is the top-level package. When there are several meta-classes with the same name, one has to use more than one top-level package (Poseidon 4.x uses the "UML" top-level package as well as the "UML2" top-level package). This causes problems in the ASMMDRModel.newASMMDRModel() method, where only one top-level package is retrieved, depending on the meta-model name used in the ATL transformation (e.g. "UML").
When using the wrong -- or too little -- top-level packages, MDR fails loading all model elements of which the meta-class is not in the provided top-level package.
Committed this patch on CVS.
Created an attachment (id=45993) Patch to bring org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant project in compliance w.r.t. 3.2 doc on Eclipse + Ant

attachment.desc: Patch for fully qualified meta-class names
Patch to bring org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant project in compliance w.r.t. 3.2 doc on Eclipse + Ant

bug.short_desc: UML2 models are not written correctly: wrong Resource factory used

long_desc.thetext:
ASMEMFModel.newASMEMFModel() uses the symbolic model name, e.g. "OUT", as a URI to create a new EMF Resource. EMF uses the file extension in the Resource URI to resolve the correct factory, reader and writer classes for the Resource. If there's no file extension, the default Ecore XMI reader and writer will be used.
This forms a problem for UML2 models created by the UML2 plug-in, which uses its own model reader and writer. The problem is most noticeable when using UML2 Profiles: profiles are stored in external files and use a special URI resolving mechanism, which is not part of EMF. Any applied stereotypes in UML2 models written by ATL cannot be read back by the UML2 plug-in. The XML contents of the files also look noticeably different: - xmi:id properties are absent - xsi:schemaLocation in the top-level element looks different
Since the real model URI is always known before the transformation, the proposal is to add a method that receives the URI in addition to the symbolic name, the meta-model and the model loader.

Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

Created an attachment (id=43700) This patch creates new models with URI
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

After applying previous patches, profiles and their stereotypes can be resolved. The profile URIs used in the created model are absolute URIs, however (i.e. platform:/resource/MyProject/profiles/MyProfile.uml2). In the source model, these URIs were relative (i.e. ../profiles/MyProfile.uml2).
This makes it difficult to move the output models (including profiles) to a different directory or use them outside Eclipse. Loading and saving the output models in the UML2 editor works around the problem for now.

I committed these patchs.
Thanks
There's still a problem if the file path contains, for example, space characters. The URI should be encoded but isn't.

bug.short_desc: Registered EMF models are unloaded in dispose(), causing an NPE on next use

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
I'm trying to define simple ANT Tasks, but there are some disapointing random messages.
First of all, this is my ANT Task :
<target name="all" depends="loadModels">
</target>
<target name="loadModels"> <!-- Load ATL metamodel --> <am3.loadModel modelHandler="EMF" name="ATL" metamodel="MOF" nsUri="http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/2005/ATL" /> <!-- Load KM3 metamodel --> <am3.loadModel modelHandler="EMF" name="KM3" metamodel="MOF" nsUri="http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/2005/KM3" /> <!-- Load current metamodel --> <am3.loadModel modelHandler="EMF" name="MM" metamodel="MOF" path="${metamodelsPath}/${metamodel_filename}" /> </target>
Not a esoteric example ;)
So, the first time i launch the ant script, i got messages telling me everything is ok. After a random number of executions (from 3 to 10), it fails and give me error message (see at the end of the post for complete message).
I don't understand the behaviour. Between succesive executions, i didn't change anything. Any help would be appreciated !!
Regards, Mikael

Hi,
I found where this issue come from. The dispose() method is sometime called by finalize() method in org.atl.engine.repositories.emf4atl.ASMEMFModel
I don't know why this method is called from time to time by the garbage collector, but it doesn't have to.
I comment its call in finalize() and everything is ok now. I know it's not a good solution, but it is the only one i found.
Hope this help
Regards, Mikael

The NPE problem occurs when a model is "loaded" from URI. In this case, the model isn't explicitly loaded, but resolved in a registry. If a resource in a registry is unloaded, it will not be reloaded on use.
A possible fix is to record for each model whether is was explicitly loaded and only unload in this case. This also requires recording extra registry entries that ATL makes, since these entries need to be unregistered before a model is unloaded.
Created an attachment (id=49049) Patch for safe unloading of EMF Resources
Created an attachment (id=49219) Eclipse Monkey scripts to look at the EMF model registry

(In reply to comment #4) > Short version: > > I believe ASMEMFModelElement.dispose() has a reasonable intent > but the means used to achieve it (i.e., calling Resource.clear() > and ResourceSet.remove()) is unwise.
Hmm, the ResourceSet used by ASMEMFModel is a private one that is used only by ATL. I don't know whether or when resources are automatically removed from a ResourceSet, but it seems safe to remove Resources that we've also added ourselves..
The same goes for Resource.unload(): this is now only called on Resources that we've explicitly loaded into our private ResourceSet (hence is not shared with other Eclipse plugins).
I do agree that called ResourceSet.remove() and Resource.unload() on shared objects is very unsafe.
> > Search for references to Resource.unload(). It is used for > EMFT Transaction support (i.e., a resource change induces unload + (re)load). > I haven't seen any other EMF-related code call Resource.unload() explicitly > like it is done in ASMEMFModelElement.
I don't like the unload() either: as references to the Resource are removed, it should be cleared up automagically. Fr�d�ric's experiences showed him otherwise, however, so he had to add this.
> > Long version: > > These problems have been vexing me for a while as well, enough to dig > deeper into finding out what's going on. > > First, I'd suggest adding Monkey scripts to monitor the "health" of EMF's > model registry with a Monkey DOM that has the following functions: > > public EPackage.Registry getDefaultEMFRegistry() { > return EPackage.Registry.INSTANCE; > } > > @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") > public List<String> getRegistryKeys(final EPackage.Registry registry) { > final Set<String> keys = (Set<String>) registry.keySet(); > final List<String> registryKeys = new ArrayList<String>(keys); > Collections.sort(registryKeys); > return registryKeys; > } > > public EPackage getEPackageIfLoaded(final EPackage.Registry registry, > final String nsURI) { > final Object ePackage = registry.get(nsURI); > if (ePackage instanceof EPackage) { > return (EPackage) ePackage; > } else { > return null; > } > } > > Then, using the attached Monkey scripts, you can monitor the state of the EMF > registry through the travails of ATL. > > The scripts produce 3 sets of numbers > tabulating the results of examining each > URI entry in the EMF registry: > > +P = there is an EPackage instance object registered at that URI > -P = either the URI maps to null or to a delegate object. > > +R = if the EPackage object has a legit. Resource object > -R = otherwise > > The 3 sets of numbers are: > > +P+R => there is an EPackage object w/ a Resource object registered at the URI > +P-R => there is an EPackage object but no Resource object registered at the > URI > -P-R => the URI points to a delegate > > My experience w/ ATL led me to propose an "invariance" claim > in a sort of "model checking" way: > > For all EMF-related operations on resources and resource contexts, > the following invariant should always be true: +P-R == 0 > > In practice, one can observe violations of this invariant property > (i.e., +P-R > 0) when an exception is thrown inside an Ant build script > that uses am3 tasks; regardless of whether the exception happens inside > an am3 task or a non-am3 task.
This is indeed exactly the problem condition. The patch should make sure that any Resource that will be unloaded is first unregistered.
However: things get more interesting below... ;-)
> > Here's my explanation of the bug: > > (see org.eclipse.ant.core.AntRunner) > > Method run = classInternalAntRunner.getMethod("run", > null); //$NON-NLS-1$ > run.invoke(runner, null); > } catch ... > } catch (Exception e) { > String message = (e.getMessage() == null) ? > InternalCoreAntMessages.AntRunner_Build_Failed__3 : e.getMessage(); > IStatus status= new Status(IStatus.ERROR, > AntCorePlugin.PI_ANTCORE, AntCorePlugin.ERROR_RUNNING_BUILD, message, e); > throw new CoreException(status); > } finally { > buildRunning= false; > > Thread.currentThread().setContextClassLoader(originalClassLoader); > } > > Notice the code that restores the original class loader. > What's the big deal about that? > > Most of the ATL tasks in org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant.tasks > use a map of "models" i.e., Map<String, ASMModel> > > For example, the am3.load task does something like: > > String name = ...; > ASMModel loadedModel = AM3AntToolkit.loadModel(name, ...); > getProject().addReference(name, loadedModel); > > The am3.atl task fetches the "in" models using getProject().getReference(name) > and for the "out" models, it does: > > ASMModel currentAsmModel = amh.newModel(name, metamodel); > getProject().addReference(name, currentASMModel); > AtlLauncher.getDefault().launch(....); > > The org.atl.engine.vm.ACTInterpreter executes the ATL code in the VM. > Before executing the operations of the *.asm ATL script, it adds all > of the models to its execution environment. > > When everything works peachy clean, the stack of VM frames will be > empty by the time the VM is finished and when the AntRunner finalization > work restores the original classloader context, there is no "junk" for the > garbage collector to cleanup on the ant classloader. > > On the other hand, when an exception unwinds the stack from somewhere in the > code of an am3 task and is caught up in the AntRunner exception handler, > the finalization work will restore the original classloader context while the > now defunct ant classloader context has a bunch of objects that haven't been > cleaned up by stack unwinding => i.e., the VM execution environment, the VM > interpreter, etc... so when the GC examines these things and finds live > references to some objects, e.g., ASMModel, it finalizes them and now > everything goes bonkers.... > > So, the moral of the story is that we have a case of subtle violation of > classloader boundaries during exception handling. I'm not sure how someone like > Stuart Halloway would describe this problem but I'm certain that somewhere, > there are a bunch of "classloader rules" that we're violating big time. >
So... I've fixed the wrong problem, since the finalization should never occur to begin with? Or do you mean that we should never mess with objects from another class loader (e.g. shared Resources)?

(In reply to comment #3) > Created an attachment (id=49049) [edit] > Patch for safe unloading of EMF Resources >
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

Nicolas' point about violating class loader rules in AM3 Ant tasks is starting to catch up with me :-/ . Bug # 158523 indicates that ASMEMFModels are not unloaded after running a normal Ant session (without thrown Exceptions).

Latest patch causes meta-models that are already registered not to be registered again. This causes problems when loading a model on top of that meta-model: this model uses the registered EPackage and not the EPackage that was just loaded from the meta-model. This problem only manifests itself when an ASMEMFModel wasn't disposed (and hence unregistered), i.e. in AM3 Ant tasks.

Created an attachment (id=50827) Patch for safe unloading of EMF Resources and postponed loading of uninitialised EMF meta-models
This patch always registers a meta-model, even if there's already a registry entry. It does so in the *local* package registry, however. This way, EMF will always use the meta-model that is registered by ATL. A warning is generated if an existing registry entry is overwritten.
This patch also includes the code for postponed loading of registered meta-models for which the Eclipse plugin has not yet been loaded by OSGI. See also Bug # 156103.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

The previous version of this patch would cause ATL to always use the default XMI resource factory. The original "init()" method has been restored, which registers the fallback resource factory in the global registry instead of the local (overriding) registry.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.
Integrated patch.

bug.short_desc: EMF4ATL does not support embedded meta-models, such as UML2 profiles

long_desc.thetext: EMF4ATL cannot find EPackages and EClasses that are wrapped inside other model elements. An example of this situation are UML2 profiles: a profile contains one or more embedded EPackages that form a little meta-model. This meta-model can be used to create Stereotype applications.

Created an attachment (id=49333) Patch for supporting wrapped meta-models
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.
Integrated patch.

bug.short_desc: EMF4ATL does not support mixed content in EMF-XSD meta-models

long_desc.thetext:
EMF can be used to create meta-models from XML schemas. This is convenient for the manipulation of structured XML data that has no meta-model yet, such as Hibernate Mapping (http://ssel.vub.ac.be/viewcvs/viewcvs.py/hibernate-mapping-3.0/).
ATL can use these meta-models with the exception of "mixed" content, such as the "xxx" string in the following XML tag:
<param name="ParamName">xxx</param>
EMF uses the FeatureMapEntry data type to represent mixed content. EMF4ATL does not support the assignment of this data type.

Created an attachment (id=49334) Patch for supporting assignment of FeatureMapEntry attributes
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.
Integrated patch.

attachment.desc: Patch for supporting assignment of FeatureMapEntry attributes

bug.short_desc: ATL does not support module-level inheritance

long_desc.thetext: ATL modules are currently stand-alone: it is not possible to reuse rules from other modules in a new module. If ATL supports module-level inheritance, a new module can import and override rules from another module.

Created an attachment (id=49335) Patch for supporting module-level inheritance
This patch allows for modules to import and override matched rules from another module. This is done by load-time ASM transformation (I like the sound of that, let's say it again: "load-time ASM transformation" ;-)).
The patch requires the root module to be specified as the main transformation and any child module (that inherit from the root module) to be specified as libraries.
This isn't optimal, since the order in which the child modules override the rules is unspecified. The user is currently responsible for avoiding conflicts between child modules. In the future, the AtlLauncher and the Eclipse user interface should support a special run configuration field for specifying a sorted list of child modules (or similar).
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

Created an attachment (id=49601) New version of AtlModuleInheritance.java, supporting attribute helpers
This version allows child modules to add their own attribute helpers.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

When considering what the term "inheritance" stands for, it turns out that it doesn't really apply to ATL modules. There are no instances of modules in a way that they can conform to a module type, sub-type or super-type. All it has in common with inheritance, is that one can extend and override the functionality of an ATL module with another module.
A better term for the submitted patch is "superimposition" of modules on top of eachother. Superimposition also indicates that modules can be stacked on top of eachother in any order at load time. Inheritance is a design time construct.
I propose to rename the AtlModuleInheritance class to AtlSuperimposeModule, which is the name I'll use in future patches (there are newer versions waiting).

Created an attachment (id=50017) Patch for supporting module superimposition
This patch uses the term "superimposition" instead of inheritance. It also creates a special parameter in the AtlLauncher for superimposed modules. Superimposed modules are no longer in the same map as libraries, which means that libraries are treated the original way and superimposed modules are now configured in a separate, sorted list.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

This patch adds module superimposition support to the launch configuration interface. It also fixes a minor bug in the MainAtlTab in which the selected model transformation field is emptied after returning to the main tab from another tab.

long_desc.thetext: When trying to debug an ATL transformation in Eclipse 3.2, several things go wrong: - Eclipse does not switch to the Debug view - The control buttons for running, stepping, etc., are greyed out - No variables can be introspected - Line number lookup in the source files doesn't work

bug.short_desc: MDR4ATL cannot save models outside an Eclipse session

long_desc.thetext:
Hi all,
On Tuesday 12 September 2006 18:58, Milan Milanovic wrote: > Hi Frédéric, > > I tested today your KM3Projector class in detail. I tried to narrow my > problem with running ATL transformation programmatically. > > It seems that when MDR is used as hanlder for both, input and output model > then output model is emtpy !
Thanks for giving more detailed information. This is something I can test against.
> > When EMF is used for input, or output then it works. > > Is anyone tried to run transformation using MDR as model handler for input > and output models ?
Actually, I can't use MDR for *output* outside Eclipse. Luckily, I did get an exception thrown at me (I use Eclipse 3.2): first, a ClassNotFoundException got thrown, saying that org.eclipse.osgi.BundleActivator was necessary. When I added that to the classpath, I got to the *real* problem: "java.lang.IllegalStateException: Workspace is closed." MDR4ATL tries to access the Eclipse Workspace for resolving URIs. This prevents MDR4ATL from saving models outside Eclipse.
This is also contrary to loading models, for which you can just use an InputStream. A command-line interface to ATL cannot use any save method with an OutputStream.
I'll submit a bug report for this...

bug.short_desc: Resolving references over multiple models fails

long_desc.thetext:
Hi Mike,
Am 27.09.2006 um 17:42 schrieb Michael R�ger:
>> >> On Wednesday 27 September 2006 09:12, Michael Rÿfffffffffffcger >> wrote: >>> Hi Matthias, >>> >>>> If the DataType is inside a separate UML profile resource, the >>>> rule does >>>> not fire. >>> >>> Yes, matched rules are only fired for all elements in the IN models. >> >> So, (yet) another solution is to add the profile as an input model >> to the >> transformation ;-). > > This has not worked for my dereference problem, because the same model > elements are seen by atl twice (one in the input model and the > other in > the referenced model). ;( > > I think the same will happen here and the rule will not fire for the > referenced elements. Mathias, please give it a try and tell us if you > succeed with the adding of the profile as a 2nd input model. I hope it > works because this way you will not need my extra dereference > transformation. > > Mike
I have given this a try (made EnterpriseAppProfile.profile.uml2 another input model). Suddenly, a very strange effect occurs: The rule fires for the referenced elements (datatype elements) but the transformed Property element in the output model does not point to the transformed Type element! It points to the original, untransformed PrimitiveType element in the UML profile model! Now, I am totally confused. ???
The output looks like this:
<Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a9" name="Date"/> <Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a10" name="void"/> <Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a11" name="String"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a12" name="licensePlate"> <type href="platform:/resource/ATL_Test/Models/ EnterpriseAppProfile.profile.uml2#_wIlIsUzcEdu93P4SMLjz7g"/> </Data.OOP.core:Property>
You see, the PrimitiveType elements Date, void and String were transformed into a9, a10 and a11, but the licensePlate property of the car does not point to a11 (i.e. String) but to the original UML model element in the EnterpriseAppProfile.profile.uml2 model resource!
The original elements in the profile looked like this:
<ownedMember xmi:type="uml:Package" xmi:id="_wIlIr0zcEdu93P4SMLjz7g" name="primitivetypes"> <ownedMember xmi:type="uml:PrimitiveType" xmi:id="_wIlIsEzcEdu93P4SMLjz7g" name="Date"/> <ownedMember xmi:type="uml:PrimitiveType" xmi:id="_wIlIsUzcEdu93P4SMLjz7g" name="String"/> <ownedMember xmi:type="uml:PrimitiveType" xmi:id="_wIlIskzcEdu93P4SMLjz7g" name="void"/> </ownedMember>
You recognize the internal id of String: "_wIlIsUzcEdu93P4SMLjz7g"? a12 points to this element instead of its transformed counterpart, a11.
How can that be possible? ATL transforms correctly but links incorrectly!
Cheers, Matthias
P.S.: The ZIP file on my web page http://www.andromda.org/atlproblem/ contains all these models, metamodels and transformations. You can easily try it yourself to reproduce the bug. Just remove the comment in the second line of UML2EnterpriseApp.atl so that it includes the profile as a second IN model: create OUT : EnterpriseApp from IN: UML2, PRO: UML2;

Created an attachment (id=51838) ATL_Test.zip
Testcase that demonstrates the bug. Tested in Eclipse 3.2

Created an attachment (id=51839) Output of the UML2EnterpriseApp.atl transformation
The output of the UML2EnterpriseApp.atl transformation shows the status of the TransientLinkSet resolve table during the transformation. The problem becomes clear during the execution of the UMLPropertyToOOPProperty rule:
UMLPropertyToOOPProperty: 'birth' UMLPropertyToOOPProperty: IN!Date
Here, the 'birth' property supposedly has IN!Date as its type. This is not true, since Date resides in the PRO model, not the IN model. The TransientLink in the links table shows this correctly:
TransientLink {rule = 'UMLPrimitiveTypeToOOPDatatype', sourceElements = {type = PRO!Date}, targetElements = {out = OUT!Date}, variables = {}},

Created an attachment (id=51840) Patch to ASMEMFModelElement that resolves the real ASMModel for each EObject
This patch ensures that ASMEMFModelElement.emf2ASM() resolves the real ASMEMFModel when converting an EObject to an ASMEMFModelElement. This means it also gives an error when it can't find the real ASMEMFModel. The previous behaviour was to just assume that the EObject was part of the same ASMEMFModel as the current (referring) ASMEMFModelElement.
Unfortunately, this patch also includes the changes for bug nr 156094. These changes haven't yet been committed to CVS.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

The patch of 2006-10-12 (id=51840) creates unwanted side effects in existing transformations. For example, the UML2Copy.atl transformation (http://ssel.vub.ac.be/viewcvs/viewcvs.py/UML2CaseStudies/uml2cs-transformations/UML2Copy.atl?rev=5479&view=markup) uses IN as input model and OUT as output model. If the IN model contains references to an external model, then the UML2Copy.atl transformation must be adapted to include that external model -- even though the external references only need to be preserved, not transformed.
It seems better to fall back to the existing behaviour of using the same model as the referring element as a "proxy" for the referred to (external) element. Of course, if that external element is actually part of one of the models that are parameters of the transformation, then no "proxy" may be used.

Created an attachment (id=52057) Patch to ASMEMFModelElement that resolves the real ASMModel for each EObject
This patch ensures that ASMEMFModelElement.emf2ASM() resolves the real ASMEMFModel when converting an EObject to an ASMEMFModelElement. It does not give an error when it can't find the real ASMEMFModel, but uses the ASMEMFModel containing the model element referring to the EObject as a "proxy" (i.e. fall back to the old behaviour). Unfortunately, this patch also includes the changes for bug nr 156094. These changes haven't yet been committed to CVS.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

Hi Dennis,
after I applied your patch and ran the UML2EnterpriseApp transformation again, the result was perfect at first:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <xmi:XMI xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:Data.EnterpriseApp.core="http:///Data/EnterpriseApp/core.ecore" xmlns:Data.OOP.core="http:///Data/OOP/core.ecore"> <Data.EnterpriseApp.core:Reference xmi:id="a1" target="a4" source="a3"/> <Data.EnterpriseApp.core:Reference xmi:id="a2" target="a5" source="a3"/> <Data.EnterpriseApp.core:Service xmi:id="a3" sourceReferences="a1 a2" name="RegistryService" methods="a6"/> <Data.EnterpriseApp.core:Entity xmi:id="a4" name="Person" properties="a14 a13 a16" targetReferences="a1"/> <Data.EnterpriseApp.core:Entity xmi:id="a5" name="Car" properties="a12 a15" targetReferences="a2"/> <Data.OOP.core:Method xmi:id="a6" name="register" instanceScope="true" parameters="a7 a8" returnType="a11"/> <Data.OOP.core:Parameter xmi:id="a7" name="owner" type="a4"/> <Data.OOP.core:Parameter xmi:id="a8" name="car" type="a5"/> <Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a9" name="String"/> <Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a10" name="Date"/> <Data.OOP.core:Type xmi:id="a11" name="void"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a12" name="owner" type="a4"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a13" name="name" type="a9"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a14" name="property" type="a5"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a15" name="licensePlate" type="a9"/> <Data.OOP.core:Property xmi:id="a16" name="birth" type="a10"/> </xmi:XMI>
But when I simply run the transformation once more, an exception occurs (see attachment). When I shutdown Eclipse and restart it (it was a runtime workbench with the ATL plugins loaded), then the same thing happens again: First time, every thing works OK, second time: the exception is thrown again.
I attach the output from the ATL console which contains the stacktrace.
Cheers Matthias

Created an attachment (id=52155) Exception stacktrace from the ATL console
This is the output in the ATL console when the exception occurs upon the second time I run the UML2EnterpriseApp transformation. -- Matthias Bohlen

(In reply to comment #7) > Created an attachment (id=52155) [edit] > Exception stacktrace from the ATL console > > This is the output in the ATL console when the exception occurs upon the second > time I run the UML2EnterpriseApp transformation. -- Matthias Bohlen >
I didn't manage to reproduce this exception. Please note that the patch you applied is not the latest patch. It should not make a difference in this case, however, since ATL should never behave different on a first run and subsequent runs.
This sounds very much like either a memory management or a model registry issue: some "history" of the first transformation run is left behind, which causes the conditions for the second run to be different from the first.
I've only very limited experience with such "history" effects: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=155673#c9
Can you tell exactly which patches you have applied? Some of the "older" patches introduced problems like this. The latest patch to Bug # 155673 indicates whenever entries in the model registry are overwritten and it indicates when ASMEMFModels are disposed (and hence also unregistered). That gives us a better chance on tracking down this issue.

bug.short_desc: Model element introspection fails during debugging

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Start debug session. 2. Choose "step over" until a model element with references shows up in the Variables window. 3. Try to expand the model element in the Variables window.
More information: Two exceptions are thrown: one local exception that goes into the Eclipse Error Log and one "remote" exception that goes into the console.
From the console exception, it becomes clear that the ATL VM LocalObjectReference.get() method does not pass a stackframe to ASMModelElement.get(). This creates problems with the latest ASMEMFModelElement, which uses the stackframe to access the available ASMModels. See also Bug # 160646.

bug.short_desc: wrong (abstract + static) or missing (final) modifiers predicates

long_desc.thetext:
(tested with MD10.5 and Aris mapping files/adapters and respective models)
* method isAbstract always evaluates to false : whatever the properties values within the model - both for classes and operations
* method isStatic always evaluates to false for operations : whatever the properties values within the model (not a surprise with Aris since this property is not xmi exported !...)
* NO method dealing with the final modifier on operations (assume it is isLeaf for classes, isReadOnly for attributes...)

was wrong with Aris xmi export : the static property IS exported - thru the ownerScope one. The mapping ownerScope/OwnerScope was just missing in the aris-xm11_all.xml file for the Operation ModelElement. Added the following lines after the visibility/Visibility mapping - and isStatic is now OK (for Aris at least) :
<Property> <Source type="Attribute" name="ownerScope"/> <Target type="Attribute">OwnerScope</Target> </Property>

noticed that the isAbstract/Abstract mapping was declared only for classes in the aris_xm11_all.xml file. So, added it too for Operations (after the ownerScope/OwnerScope as described above in comment #1) and it works too. But the bug is still there for classes...

Sorry : isAbstract also works for classes (just messed up in my extensions calls). So, finally :
* isAbstract aris_xm11_all.xml file needs to be completed as to define the mapping isAbstract/Abstract for Operation
* isStatic aris_xm11_all.xml file needs to be completed as to define the mapping ownerScope/OwnerScope for Operation
* NO method dealing with the final modifier on operations (assume it is isLeaf for classes, isReadOnly for attributes...)

bug.short_desc: ATL + AM3 configuration patches for Eclipse 3.1 => 3.2

long_desc.thetext:
For a while, I've used ATL/AM3/AMW on Mac (at home) and Linux (at work) with various versions of Eclipse 3.2. I'm attaching a patch to files of the ATL & AM3 plugins that, IMHO, require some fixes to make sure the capabilities work properly.
The patches fall into 3 categories:
- build.properties / .classpath
These are necessary to ensure that current dependencies on third-party libraries are known to the compiler so that, at runtime, the plugins won't run into annoying "class not found" problems with things like antlr/... or for the mdr libraries.
AM3 has a missing dependency on ant.jar which can cause subtle and confusing classloader problems as I reported earlier: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=141461
I made the patch on the mac and the .classpath for: org.eclipse.gmt/AM3/org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant/.classpath needs to be cleaned up to get a dependency on JRE1.4 to ensure that Java 1.4 users can run the AM3 ant tasks properly without running into java bytecode version incompatibilities.
- source code portability
org.eclipse.gmt.atl.oclquery.core/src/org/eclipse/gmt/atl/oclquery/core/DummyFile.java org.atl.eclipse.adt.editor/src/org/atl/eclipse/adt/ui/text/AtlSourceViewerConfiguration.java
- PDE changes from 3.1 => 3.2
This one is a bit subtle and I can't pinpoint what specifically changed in PDE but it breaks AM3 at startup if it isn't fixed:
org.eclipse.gmt/AM3/org.eclipse.am3.core/src/org/eclipse/am3/core/AM3Handler.java
-- Nicolas.
Created an attachment (id=41416) Patches to ATL and AM3 for Eclipse calisto portability.
These patches work for me on Mac OSX (10.4.6) and linux (RHEL4) using Java 1.5 (and Java 1.4 in a few places such as AM3 ant tasks)
Applied this patch on CVS code.

The patches submitted before are insufficient; essentially, my sandbox at home worked but my sandbox at work didn't and I couldn't figure out what the difference was...
Well, the gist of the answer boils down to 3 important aspects of building ant tasks for Eclipse:
http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/ant_developing.htm http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/extension-points/org_eclipse_ant_core_extraClasspathEntries.html http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/ant_contributing_task.htm
The new patches make small but important changes:
1) unzip the ant task source code and let PDE build it
2) add to CVS the PDE settings required to make sure that the AM3 ant tasks will be loaded on the ant classloader.
3) fix the path of the ant tasks in the xml library
There is also a minor bug I ran into when running some ant build.xml files that use am3.* tasks (finally!) Some of the GMT examples still don't work as advertised but there's a lot of progress w.r.t. the previous situation where it wasn't clear why things worked sometimes vs didn't other times.
Now, the answer = the patches + links for RTFM on Eclipse & Ant.
Created an attachment (id=45994) Bring org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant project in compliance w.r.t. Eclipse 3.2 guidelines for building ant tasks
Created an attachment (id=45995) fix to minor bug in ATL's ASMModel

attachment.desc: Patches to ATL and AM3 for Eclipse calisto portability.
Bring org.eclipse.gmt.am3.tools.ant project in compliance w.r.t. Eclipse 3.2 guidelines for building ant tasks
fix to minor bug in ATL's ASMModel

bug.short_desc: EMF4ATL does not resolve proxy EPackages - NPE on using uninitialised meta-models

long_desc.thetext:
EMF4ATL throws a NullPointerException when trying to use uninitialised EMF meta-models. This happens for Eclipse EMF-based plugins that provide a meta-model, such as UML2, IODT ontology tools (http://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/tech/semanticstk), HibernateMapping30 (http://ssel.vub.ac.be/viewcvs/viewcvs.py/hibernate-mapping-3.0/), etc.
The NPE is thrown when EMF4ATL tries to access the Resource of the EPackage, which turns out to be null.

(In reply to comment #0) > The NPE is thrown when EMF4ATL tries to access the Resource of the EPackage, > which turns out to be null.
It turns out the NPE is thrown on accessing the EPackage ("pack"), which is already null. This means the EMF package registry itself returns null for the given nsURI.
I'm currently testing a modification that postpones loading the extent. On the first call to getExtent(), the ASMEMFModel should try to load the extent again. The assumption here is that getExtent() is only called after loading a model that is an instance of this meta-model.

This bug is related to the way OSGI works in Eclipse: an Eclipe plugin is only loaded after the first access to one of it's classes. For EMF plugins, this means that a meta-model is not available in the EMF registry before the plugin is loaded. The EMF plugin is loaded once a model is actually loaded (class access). The startup code of the EMF plugin then registers the meta-model.
Patch with id 50827 of Bug # 155673 addresses this issue.
Integrated patch 50827 of Bug # 155673.

Created an attachment (id=55481) Patch that rolls back init() behaviour
> Integrated patch 50827 of Bug # 155673.
This patch used the local registry to register the "*" fallback resource factory. The fallback resource factory must however be registered against the global registry, otherwise _all_ global registrations will be overriden.
This patch also removes the call to addAllReferencedExtents() in the constructor, since the extent may not have been loaded yet.
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.
Reopened this bug
Integrated patch

attachment.desc: Patch that rolls back init() behaviour

bug.short_desc: uml tag values of type 'int' can't be processed

long_desc.thetext:
Only tag values of uml type 'Integer' can be processed by the xpand workflow.
When an uml tag value is defined as 'int' the xpand editor is not able to resolve the tag value. The xpand workflow can't process that tag too.

Seems to be a tooling problem. Here are my observations using MD 12.0: - Defined two tagged values for some stereotype, one of type 'int' ("intTag") the other of type 'Integer' ("integerTag") - Defined values for the tags in a stereotyped class - exported to EMF UML2
Result: The "intTag" value is *not* defined in the export, but the "integerTag" is.
--------------------EXPORT----------------------- <ownedMember xmi:type="uml:Class" xmi:id="_yoOWOLmyEduhPO2n50lewA" name="Book"> <eAnnotations xmi:id="_yoOWObmyEduhPO2n50lewA" source="appliedStereotypes"> <contents xmi:type="Persistence_0:Persistence__Entity" xmi:id="_yoOWOrmyEduhPO2n50lewA" integerTag="987654321"/> --------------------EXPORT-----------------------
Reported this bug to NoMagic.
Added hint in the UML2 adapter reference docs.

Created an attachment (id=59045) an oaw project that documents the problem
The problematic int value tag usage can be found in: src/main/resources/templates/Template.oaw, ln. 20
Remove the comment an you will see that the int-tag can not be resolved. The workflow also generates an error.

The int-tag resolution problem still exists. The attached project can be used to verify the issue. see: src/main/resources/templates/Template.xpt, ln. 20
The tag is exported correctly (by MagicDraw 12.0). That can be seen in the file: src/main/resources/uml/int_model.uml2 (Data.myPackage.X.p1 & p2)
When you remove the comment in ln. 20 of Template.xpt, the issue gets visible in the IDE. The workflow fails in that case too.

bug.short_desc: AM3 Ant tasks need to implement the "setProject(..)" method

long_desc.thetext:
I followed w/ the debugger what happens here.
1) In TaskAdapter:
setProjectM = c.getMethod("setProject", new Class[] {Project.class});
The "getMethod" is invoked starting from LoadModelTask successively up the inheritance hierarchy. When it reaches:
org.apache.tools.ant.ProjectComponent
we eventually get to calling: Class.searchMethods(...) where methods includes the desired "setProject(..)" method from ProjectComponent.
private static Method searchMethods(Method[] methods, String name, Class[] parameterTypes) { Method res = null; String internedName = name.intern(); for (int i = 0; i < methods.length; i++) { Method m = methods[i]; if (m.getName() == internedName && arrayContentsEq(parameterTypes, m.getParameterTypes()) && (res == null || res.getReturnType().isAssignableFrom(m.getReturnType()))) res = m; } ...
When the loop reaches the "setProject(...)" method, the comparison of method parameters fails:
arrayContentsEq(parameterTypes, m.getParameterTypes())
Here, parameterTypes is an array of 1 entry for org.apache.tools.ant.Project but the two objects are not exactly identical in the sense of the criteria in Class.arrayContentsEq(Object[] a1, Object[] a2)
I'm attaching a screenshot. Look at the variables window which shows you that we have 2 objects that are not "==" and yet represent the "same" org.apache.tools.ant.Project class.
Seems to me like a class loader problem but I'm really unclear where it is coming from.
Created an attachment (id=41274) Screenshot of the debugger at the root symptom of the bug
Resolved with patches of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=141698

bug.short_desc: KM3 EnumLiteral objects need a *unique* value when mapped to ECORE EEnumLiteral objects

long_desc.thetext:
The org.atl.eclipse.km3/src/org/atl/eclipse/km3/resources/KM32EMF.asm transformation is the code that defines how KM3's Enumeration + EnumLiteral objects are mapped into ECORE's EEnum and EEnumLiteral objects.
In ECORE, an EEnumLiteral object has an optional 'Value' attribute (EInt) but:
- the default value is 0 - the value must be unique
Currently, KM32ECORE.asm does not specify the value of EEnumLiteral objects created for KM3 EnumLiteral objects.
This means that the KM3 model:
enumeration Broken { literal A; literal B; }
will create a broken ECORE model where A and B will be EEnumLiteral objects with no specified value. By default, A.value = B.value = 0. This is a violation of the unicity constraint on EEnumLiteral.value within the scope of an ECORE EEnum object.

Ecore!EEnumLiteral are now created with a value equal to their position in the list of KM3!EnumLiterals of their owning KM3!Enumeration.
Thanks for reporting.
Fr�d�ric

bug.short_desc: Problem when calling an injector in "AM3.loadModel" ANT tasks with MDR as model handler

long_desc.thetext:
The following task works well:
<am3.loadModel modelHandler="MDR" name="KM3" metamodel="MOF" path="KM3.xmi"/>
But the following task causes an error:
<am3.loadModel modelHandler="MDR" name="KM3model" metamodel="KM3" path="${sourceModel}"> <injector name="ebnf"> <param name="name" value="KM3"/> <classpath> <pathelement location="KM3-importer.jar"/> </classpath> </injector> </am3.loadModel>

This error seems not related to the AM3 ANT tasks. With other metamodels (e.g. KM3_2006) and its injector, there is no error.
The bug seems to be related to KM3_2007.

long_desc.thetext:
The current (CVS 10/05/2006) AtlModelHandler.getDefault() method doesn't check whether Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns something useful. Outside Eclipse, it returns null. This causes ATL to throw a NullPointerException, where it should have thrown the RuntimeException("Model handler for " + repository + " not found. You may need to install a model handler plugin.") or perhaps something of not being able to access the Eclipse extension registry.
If one wants to use AtlMDRModelHandler outside Eclipse, it would be nice if AtlMDRModelHandler can register directly with AtlModelHandler instead of with Eclipse? Otherwise, the command line interface can only provide a fixed number of hard-coded AtlModelHandlers by direct instantiation. If AtlMDRModelHandler can add itself to the defaultModelHandlers field of AtlModelHandler, the problems seems to be solved.

Created an attachment (id=41098) Checks if Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns null and adds registerDefaultHandler() method for use outside Eclipse
This patch checks if Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns null and throws a RuntimeException with appropriate message if it does. It also adds a static registerDefaultHandler() method, which allows Java programs outside Eclipse to add new model handlers programmatically.

(In reply to comment #1) > Created an attachment (id=41098) [edit] > Checks if Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns null and adds > registerDefaultHandler() method for use outside Eclipse > > This patch checks if Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns null and throws a > RuntimeException with appropriate message if it does. It also adds a static > registerDefaultHandler() method, which allows Java programs outside Eclipse to > add new model handlers programmatically. >
Signed off by Dennis Wagelaar <dennis.wagelaar@vub.ac.be> to be published under the Eclipse Public License v.1.0 (http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html) or any later version.

I committed this patch.
Thanks again Dennis ;-)

attachment.desc: Checks if Platform.getExtensionRegistry() returns null and adds registerDefaultHandler() method for use outside Eclipse

long_desc.thetext:
The EMF 2.1 vs. EMF 2.2 difference has a visible effect on the KM32EMF transformation which, given a simple KM3 metamodel like this:
package Foo { class Bar {} }
produces an EMF model with 2 "Bar" EClass objects instead of one:
Foo!Bar Bar
Briefly, during the ATL transformation process, the ATL virtual machine constructs a bunch of objects (e.g., matched & called rules) during a phase where these objects will be part of the model's resource "extent" (in ECORE).
In a subsequent phase, the virtual machine sets the attributes of all of the objects it has previously created such as name, type and, for MOF!EPackage, eClassifiers and eSubpackages.
For example:
rule Package { from e : KM3!Package to c : MOF!EPackage ( name <- e.name, eClassifiers <- e.contents->select(e | e.oclIsKindOf(KM3!Classifier)), eSubpackages <- e.contents->select(e | e.oclIsKindOf(KM3!Package)), ... }
During this phase, the virtual machine calls an internal "set" operation to update the various attributes 'name', 'eClassifiers' and 'eSubpackages'...
The problem is that whenever an EObject is added either somewhere in a list of 'eClassifiers' or 'eSubpackages', that object must no longer be a "toplevel" object of the model otherwise the object will be reachable from two paths:
1) as a "toplevel" object - e.g.: model.getExtent().getContents() 2) as a "contained" object in another object's eClassifiers/eSubpackages
If, as I suspect, 'eClassifiers' and 'eSubpackages' define the semantics of object containement in ECORE, then I believe that unique path reachability should be a typestate invariant property of ECORE models.
I have checked the fix by applying the KM32EMF transformation to several KM3 metamodels in: org.eclipse.am3.zoos.atlantic and comparing the results with the ECORE models in org.eclipse.am3.zoos.atlantEcore. It seems to be OK.
More fixes are needed, e.g., to ensure the same unique path reachability typestate invariant property holds in the UI code for the ATL outline.
Created an attachment (id=42925) Path to ASMEMFModelElement.java

Tests are ok for me for Eclipse 3.1/EMF 2.1 and Eclipse 3.2/EMF 2.2.
Thanks for your contribution Nicolas.

bug.short_desc: Iterative output patterns do not work in lazy rules

long_desc.thetext:
Any attempt to use iterative output patterns in lazy rules seems to trigger an error in the ATL compiler.
The file dump.txt contains the console dump from an attempt to compile the script in file test1.atl. The script in test2.atl, that only differs from the other by having the iterative pattern in a matched rule, compiled fina and works as expected.
Created an attachment (id=44531) console dump from an attempt to compile test1.atl
Created an attachment (id=44532) the script that does not compile
Created an attachment (id=44533) the script that does compile

This behavior is actually *normal*.
Iterative target patterns are being deprecated in favor of lazy rules.
Therefore, old program with such patterns in standard rules still work. But new programs cannot use them in lazy rules.
Thanks for reporting this anyway. This entry may serve as a documentation of this *feature*.

attachment.desc: console dump from an attempt to compile test1.atl
the script that does not compile

bug.short_desc: Add the ability to get the resource URI with EMF repository

long_desc.thetext:
When generating a weaving model, it is a shame that we are not able to get the models resources URIs. This patch enable it in a similar way to allInstances() operation. If you do MM!Element.resourceURI() you will get the metamodel resource URI If you do MM!Element.resourceURIOf("model_name") you will get model resource URI It is a quick and dirty hack but it works :D
This patch apply to org.atl.engine.repositories.emf4atl/ASMModelElement.java
It has been tested with the latest CVS version of ATL.
Regards, Mika�l
Created an attachment (id=46701) Patch for org.atl.engine.repositories.emf4atl\src\org\atl\engine\repositories\emf4atl\ASMEMFModelElement
Closed as WONTFIX

bug.short_desc: Problem generating variables references in HOT (Ecore2ATL)

long_desc.thetext:
A bug appear in the new CVS version of ATL/AM3 (it already worked 3 weeks ago). In a HOT, in order to make reference to a variable, i have to create a VariableExp like this :
thisModuleVar : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- thisModuleVarDecl )
Every uses of this kind of construct results in blank with Ecore2ATL. The generated ATL model (.ecore) is correct but the extraction in ATL concrete syntax fails.
First example: I'd like to create a call to "thisModule.mymodel" global variable
thisModuleVarDecl : ATL!VariableDeclaration ( varName <- 'thisModule' ), thisModuleVar : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- thisModuleVarDecl ), stmt_model_source : ATL!NavigationOrAttributeCallExp ( name <- 'mymodel', source <- thisModuleVar )
The results after serialization : ".model" without the "thisModule" before the dot.
Second example: I'd like to do a binding between a variable in a SimpleOutPatternElement and another SimpleOutPatternElement like this (this is what i expected) :
model: MM!Model( name <- 'mymodel', aModelRef <- outModelRef ), outModelRef: MM!ModelRef( name <- 'mymodelref' )
For this i did : [...] opeModel_leftModel : ATL!Binding ( propertyName <- 'aModelRef', value <- opeaModelRef_var ), [...] opeaModelRef : ATL!SimpleOutPatternElement ( varName <- 'outModelRef', bindings <- Sequence{[...]}, type <- [...] ), opeaModelRef_var : ATL!VariableExp ( referredVariable <- opeaModelRef ) [...]
But i get this:
model: MM!Model( name <- 'mymodel', aModelRef <- ), outModelRef: MM!ModelRef( name <- 'mymodelref' )
despite the ATL model is also correct from this point of view (everything is well referenced etc.) It must come from the Ecore2ATL extractor (i think).
Sorry for the lack of patch :/
Regards, Mika�l
Bug corrected. There was a problem in the TCS of ATL when using "OclUndefinedExp" and "VariableExp" elements. We replaced it with a correct version.

bug.short_desc: Search for Java method too restrictive

long_desc.thetext: In an EMF model, it is not possible to call a Java method with primitive type parameters on a model object. For example, I have an ATL transformation that creates as output a UML profile. To create extensions I want to call the stereotype method createExtension(org.eclipse.uml2.uml.Class metaclass, boolean isRequired). ATL can't find this method, but if I change the method to take a Boolean parameter it works.

Created an attachment (id=49799) Match primitive types and wrapper classes.

Integrated patch.
Thanks ;-)

bug.short_desc: Memory Leak during execution of model transformation

long_desc.thetext:
There are some memory leaks during execution of an ATL model transformation. Here is the report of Markus Herrmannsd�rfer: -------------------------------------------------------------- I am trying to use ATL for model migration between two different versions of a metamodel.[...]
My first step was to generate a complete identity transformation and to run it on a big model (roughly 100.000 instances or 10 MB of XML data). Later the generated transformation should be edited in order to adjust it to the new metamodel version. The transformation takes 1:30 min which is not a problem, but about 100 MB of memory used during transformation will never be freed again (even after manually executing garbage collection). That means that I can only execute a small amount of transformation in a chain, before my eclipse instance runs out of memory. [...] --------------------------------------------------------------

Created an attachment (id=59875) Sample project to test Memory Leak
Sample project provided by Markus Herrmannsd�rfer to test Memory Leak problems

The problem seems to solve itself when running the transformation through AM3 ant tasks: about 30 seconds after executing the build.xml file, you get your memory back ;-). That may be because Eclipse cleans up the mess after Ant runs :-/.

Bug resolved:
- OclType.subtypes was keeping a reference on each model element - Each metamodel was having a reference to every model conforming to him (ASMModel.submodels)
Bug closed

Thanks guys! Is the fix in head?
- ian

Yes, it is in head ;)
(In reply to comment #5) > Thanks guys! Is the fix in head? > > - ian >

With this change the Families2Persons transformation works as expected without throwing exceptions.

The execution of a workflow file produces a [workflow-file].log logfile by default. This is an unwanted side effect, especially when providing an explicit log4j.properties for logging configuration. At least it should be configurable (default: off). It could default to "on" when no log4j.properties is provided.

I don't like the .log file either. Moreover, producing this logfile implies a dependency on log4j. This is unnecessary, since all the rest is being logged with commons-logging.
To be precise, the following classes produce the dependency:
* oaw.workflow.logging.LoggingAppender: used for logging to the .log file * oaw.workflow.logging.LogViewLogger: totally bogus class. unused afaik. and it better be not used... * oaw.workflow.WorkflowRunner: registers the LoggingAppender

http://www.openarchitectureware.org/forum/viewtopic.php?forum=2&showtopic=1584
Sven Efftinge, Tuesday, July 25 2006 @ 09:23 AM CEST The 'hard-wired' logging stuff has already been removed in the 4.1 stream.
The Namespace metaclass derives from ModelElement. It must derive from Element, because the references 'Provision', 'Requirement' and 'Documentation' must also exist for Namespace elements.
Created an attachment (id=36960) New structure

Because Namespace is defined in core package it was not possible to have UML from Namespaces to other elements and vice versa.
The solution is that a new class "UMLNamespace" was derived from core Namespace which defines the needed associations "requirement" and "provision" to class Dependency. The bidirectional association between ModelElement and Dependency was splitted. The association roles "client" and "supplier" now point to Element instead of ModelElement.
The classes Package and Subsystem are now derived from UMLNamespace, so they now have associations "Provision", "Requirement" and a property "Documentation".

If I have a metaclass A and a metaclass B, with A having a to-many reference to B (let's say it's called bs) then writing an xTend trafo that says someA.bs.add( someOtherSetOrList ) will procude a null evaluation. You have to use someA.setBs( someOtherSetOrList )
In case you just want to add one other set that's not a problem, but if you want to add multiple things, you'd have to union the various sets together. Not very nice.
Also, since the add(...) operation is available in extend (and so is addAll(...)) it should work....

seems that the 'bs' reference is not initialized with an empty collection. xtend is not responsible for a proper initialization of model elements. If this is not the case could you please add the NPE stacktrace (or the line and file the NPE is produced)

I have to generate files (like Visual Studio project files) in which newlines are relevant, so I was trying to use the whitespace control feature, as documented in the Xpand manual.
There is says:
"... Additionally, all following whitespace including the first newline character (\r\n is handled as one character) is also removed."
Well, it does not seem to work that way:
If I have this code in the macro (I use simple << and >> because I don't know how to generate the correct ones in the mail editor):
LINESTART <<IF "a" == "a" ->>
We have a <<ENDIF ->>
LINEEND
I would expect to get the following result:
LINESTART We have a LINEEND
But what I get instead is:
LINESTART
We have a
LINEEND
The only way I found to put everything on one line I the following one, which is not very readable:
LINESTART <<IF "a" == "a" ->> We have a <<ENDIF ->> LINEEND
In other words, it does not seem that the newline character following the
->> is actually removed. At least not in all situations.
If you can look into this, it would also be very practical to have a way to simply tell the generator to ignore a newline, some compilers do that if you have a \ character right before the newline. An empty command like
<<->>
that would ignore all the following whitespace including the first newline character would be very practical, since it would allow to split long lines in the macros. And one could also use this syntax, which would be much more readable:
LINESTART <<->>
<<IF "a" == "a" ->>
We have a <<->>
<<ENDIF ->>
LINEEND
TOBEFIXEDIN411
FIXED
FIXED

i'm using 4.1.0.200607141551 from the update site, EMF-based UML2 with a profile that defines a stereotype "core::PlexxPackage" on uml::Package. the following template fails:
�DEFINE Root FOR core::PlexxPackage� �EXPAND Package::Package FOR this� �ENDDEFINE�
�DEFINE Root FOR uml::Package� �IF core::PlexxPackage.isInstance(this)� �ERROR "oh oh"� �ENDIF� �ENDDEFINE�
i think i shouldn't receive an "oh oh" message, but instead expand Package::Package.xpt, shouldn't i? the given example is invoked for the top-level model element, maybe that's the problem. changing the order in the template does not help.

i just gave it one more try and found out that it's the order of the metamodels as they are specified in the generator component in the workflow.
this does not work:
<component id="generator" class="org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.Generator"> <metaModel id="EcoreMM" class="org.openarchitectureware.type.emf.EmfMetaModel" metaModelPackage="org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EcorePackage"/> <metaModel id="UML2MM" class="org.openarchitectureware.uml2.UML2MetaModel" /> <metaModel id="coreMM" class="org.openarchitectureware.uml2.profile.ProfileMetaModel" profile="core.profile.uml" /> <expand value="templates::Root::Root FOR coreTestModel"/> <outlet> <path value="${srcGenPath}/"/> </outlet> </component>
this does: [putting the profile metamodel before the UML metamodel]
<component id="generator" class="org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.Generator"> <metaModel id="EcoreMM" class="org.openarchitectureware.type.emf.EmfMetaModel" metaModelPackage="org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EcorePackage"/> <metaModel id="coreMM" class="org.openarchitectureware.uml2.profile.ProfileMetaModel" profile="core.profile.uml" /> <metaModel id="UML2MM" class="org.openarchitectureware.uml2.UML2MetaModel" /> <expand value="templates::Root::Root FOR coreTestModel"/> <outlet> <path value="${srcGenPath}/"/> </outlet> </component>
is there anything we can do about that?
Are sure, that core::PlexxPackage stereotype really extends uml::Package? Could you provide the profile file (or a similar one)?

yes, core::PlexxPackage extends uml::Package, and that might also be part of the problem: the model root element is of course a uml::Model, which extends uml::Package.
i've sent the profile to your private email address (non-disclosure and stuff...)

The implementation askes the metamodel implementations in the configured order. If an implementation 'feels' responsible for an object (i.e. returns a type) it is considered the actual type, as along as the following metamodel implementations don't return a more specific type (i.e. a type that extends the actual type).
In your case the first implementation (Built-In Metamodel) returns 'Object' The second (EMF) returns null The third (UML2) returns 'uml::Model' which is a specialization of 'Object' The last (profile) returns 'core::PlexxPackage' which is *not* more special than 'uml::Model' as they are not assignable to each other (both just extend uml::Package)
So, I guess at least for the time being you have to know the described behaviour and configure your workflow appropriately. If you don't have any further suggestions I would like you to close this bug. I will add a respective paragraph to the expression documentation. Thanx!

so the problem is that an object can be an instance of multiple classifiers, in this case uml::Model and core::PlexxPackage, an on the meta-meta-model level, oaw::Object.getType() can only return one (the most specific) type.
what if oaw::Object.getTypes() would return both uml::Model and core::Package? in my case, that would solve the problem, since it would invoke the core::PlexxPackage template (the most specific that is defined). but if i had these templates
�DEFINE Root FOR core::PlexxPackage� ... �ENDDEFINE�
�DEFINE Root FOR uml::Model� ... �ENDDEFINE�
�DEFINE Root FOR uml::Package� ... �ENDDEFINE�
that would be ambigious. so returning multiple types would have no benefit. except that maybe a user could now define the preferred template to be evaluated by the order in the xpt file, and not through the order given in the workflow, which in my eyes would be more logical.
but anyway, i can live with a note in the documentation about the fact and close this bug. should we ever require an object to be an instance of multiple types, we can open a new enhancement request.

In the referenced forum thread problems are reported using ARIS.
ARIS Output ============= <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <XMI xmi.version="1.1" xmlns:UML="//org.omg/UML/1.4">
leads to: ============= 18000 ERROR DTMWrapper$DummyErrorListener - XPath parser error javax.xml.transform.TransformerException: Nach dem Token '/' oder '//' wurde ein Positionsschritt erwartet.
The leading slashes in the namespace URI lead to the exception. The URI should not be interpreted by the XPathParser.
Similar problem arises with PowerDesigner: http://www.openarchitectureware.org/forum/viewtopic.php?forum=2&showtopic=1811

The problem is quite common. These links give more information: http://www.stylusstudio.com/xsllist/200504/post40640.html http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.text.xml.xalan.java.user/4431 http://www.mail-archive.com/xalan-dev@xml.apache.org/msg24167.html
Some links lead to changes from Xalan 2.3 to 2.7. Normally the problem should not exist with Xalan 2.7, but oAW uses exactly this version.
------------------ quote -------------------------- Xalan-J 2.3.1 treated the expression // as equivalent to /descendant-or-self::node(), but only the latter is a syntactically correct XPath expression. You should be able to use the latter with the Xalan-J 2.7 Interpretive processor. ------------------ quote --------------------------

Implemented a FilterReader which filters the leading slashes from the namespace URI. (UMLNamespaceFixFilterReader)
ARISAdapter wraps the CharacterStream with this reader by overriding openDesign() method.
- UMLNamespaceFixFilterReader 1.1 - ARISAdapter 1.2

Having (EMF) model classes separated in separate model packages (see test.test2.CAA) the polymorphism mechanism of XPAND fails.
test.A test.BA -> (inherits from) test.A test.Package (Top Model Component) |_ items (Reference on a Set of type test.A)
test.CA -> test.A test.test2.CAA -> test.CA
For Instances of Type A and BA the correct XPAND templates are called. When resolving instances of type CAA a template for the target type 'Object' is required (the content type of the model set though would be A, the correct type CAA). Additionally an exception is logged to the console (provided at the end of this bug entry).
This is a blocker since it prevents separating models into packages and using specialization/generalization.
My environment is: - Eclipse 3.2.0 - M20060629-1905 - EMF 2.2.0 200606272057 - oaW 4.1, RC2. - JDK 1.5.0_06 (- SuSE Linux 10.0)

bug.short_desc: [release] Maven repository does not contain oAW4.1 Final

By now when starting the workflow there is no version reported in the log. It would be nice for error tracking to print out the exact oAW version, also for interim builds.
FIXED.

Not fixed sufficiently. In WorkflowRunner the version number is hard coded:
----------------------- logger.info("openArchitectureWare 4.1.1 -- (c) 2005, 2006 openarchitectureware.org and contributors"); -----------------------
This should be more flexible by reading the version number from some central location. Further, some build number should be included.
When some build is released this central version number should be increased automatically by the build process.
I think the best way is to read the manifest file:
----MANIFEST.MF---- Bundle-Version: 4.1.1.qualifier
When a build is done this is replaced like wanted: Bundle-Version: 4.1.0.200608101443

Introduced a new method getVersion() in the workflow runner, which reads the Manifest of the core.workflow plugin. In an installation the exact build number is reported as e.g. "4.1.1, Build 200609291913". This feature only works when the plugin is deployed, but not in a development workspace. As a fallback the version "4.x Development" is reported.

bug.short_desc: bad performance when generating from a model containing a large list

long_desc.thetext:
I use the xpand2.Generator on a very simple model containing a list of a few thousand entries. Calling a very simple template takes a very long time and CPU usage goes up to 100%.
For example: 2000 elements in the list generating 4000 lines takes 20 seconds 8000 elements in the list generating 16000 lines takes 160 seconds
I think this is just way too much, there might be some effective caching mechanisms reducing this time significantly...
The model contains a list of events, where all possible type of events in the metamodel are derived from a base event type. The metamodel has a bidirectional reference between the list of events and each event (making it unidirectional does not change the timings significantly, however).
The template basically contains a DEFINE for each type of event (using polymorphism), each producing a text output of a few lines. All DEFINEs are contained in a single file.
I packaged a sample project demonstrating these issues and I will try to add it to this bug report.

Created an attachment (id=48732) zipped project to demonstrate the perfomance issues
Adjust the number of elements to create in the list of the model (see components/ModelCreator.java) and run the workflow to observe the performance.

Thanks, for the project!
Seems that the "suppress-newline feature" (the hyphen) is implemented somewhat expensive :-(.
If you remove the hyphens from the templates the respective times are:
2000 elements in the list generating 4000 lines takes 750 ms 8000 elements in the list generating 16000 lines takes 1906 ms
I will have a closer look, but for now you should consider not to use the hyphens.

Well, "somewhat expensive" is quite a diplomatic expression for quite an unexpected impact, one single hyphen at the end of a DEFINE statement seems to make the workflow slower by a factor greater than 10...wow!
Maybe you should change the syntax from '-' to '+++' to make the user more aware of the side effects of this ;-)
Not using hyphens is a problem for me at the moment, as the output format is newline- and whitespace-aware (and therefore depends on newlines only occuring at certain places)... => let me know when a fixed version or a patch is available...
TOBEFIXEDIN411
FIXED
FIXED

attachment.desc: zipped project to demonstrate the perfomance issues

long_desc.thetext:
Fixed.
- AssocRefines.xpt 1.2
Fix verified.

bug.short_desc: Problem with ecore references to other meta models (containment = false)

long_desc.thetext:
OAW does not seem to recognize reference attributes (containment = false) whose type is defined in another (referenced) Ecore model. All other attributes of a meta class instance can be accessed, and the generated java code (meta model implementation) looks o.k.
As an example, we've modified some OAW samples: the class Entity defined in data.ecore has a new attribute "type" which references a meta class defined in type.ecore (new project oaw4.demo.emf.type). The template file "Root.xpt" in oaw4.demo.emf.datamodel.generator/templates includes a new template "Type FOR Entity" which tries to access the new "type" attribute. The template editor displays a problem: "Unknown data::Entiy property, variable, type or enumeration literal 'type'". To reproduce, import the 3 projects contained in the attachment and reevaluate the template (resave template file "Root.xpt").
Created an attachment (id=49406) 3 eclipse projects to reproduce problem
I have had exactly the same problem yesterday.

OAW runtime works despite the problems displayed in Eclipse if all referenced meta models are specified in the workflow's generator component.
However, the generator does NOT issue a warning if a model reference cannot be resolved, instead it instanciates an empty model instance with no data... Especially, platform references (platform:/...) cannot be resolved, file references seem to be required.

Two observations:
1. Workflow In the workflow component the metamodels must be explicitly listed, not just referenced. Works: <metaModel id="mm" class="org.openarchitectureware.type.emf.EmfMetaModel"> <metaModelPackage value="data.DataPackage"/> </metaModel> <metaModel id="mmtype" class="org.openarchitectureware.type.emf.EmfMetaModel"> <metaModelPackage value="type.TypePackage"/> </metaModel>
Error: (The one mentioned in the bug description) <metaModel idRef="mm" /> <metaModel id="mmtype" class="org.openarchitectureware.type.emf.EmfMetaModel"> <metaModelPackage value="type.TypePackage"/> </metaModel>
2. oAW nature The reported error goes away if we patch the ecore file that contains the cross file reference, i.d. data.ecore: Replace in line 17 eType="ecore:EClass ../../oaw4.demo.emf.type/metamodel/type.ecore#//MyExternalDataType" with eType="ecore:EClass platform:/resource/oaw4.demo.emf.type/metamodel/type.ecore#//MyExternalDataType"
The is particularly striking because oAW can't handle platform URIs elsewhere. Unfortunately, if the model is modified using the Eclipse Ecore Model Editor, this change will be overwritten. But I don't know how to force Eclipse to write platform URIs instead. (IHMO, platform URIs should be preferred to relative paths in Ecore models anyway.) I consider this observation less a workaround, but a hint to the oAW developers how to fix the issue.
Created an attachment (id=50047) corrected workflow, patched ecore model
FIXED
du bist ein schatz :-)
FIXED

The current log output is not very useful. Instead of seeing that a component of a specific type has been started, I would rather like information about what the component does; e.g. * an XMI Reader should report which file it reads * a constraint check should show the constraint file it used * a transformation component should show the top level expression
To implement this, I would like to add an operation getLogString() to the WorkflowComponent interface that can be implemented to return a useful log message. The default can stay as it is now.
Why can't we just use the commons logging api?
It's not about the logging technology, it's rather about the log's content! So I want to provide some standardized means of how *useful* log output is created.

In the WorkflowComponentWithID interface there's a new method getLogMessage() that returns the text to be output. In AbstractWorkflowComponent it is implemented 'empty', so you don't have to care in all component implementations.
I would like to have a fucntion that picks all objects in a list that are *not* of a specific subtype.

How often do you need that?
Couldn't you just write 'myList.without(myList.typeSelect(MyType))' in that case?
I could, but adding this additional function is also not a lot of effort. Even I can (and probably will :-)) add it.
will not be fixed.
will not be fixed.

Assume you are using a M2M transformation in order to generate a model file, e.g. a meta model. As for example in uml2ecore, where I use an M2M to create a ecore file from a uml2 model.
Now consider, you have a project structure as follows: * theProject * src workflow.oaw * src-gen
Assume you want to write the generated .ecore file into the src-gen folder, so that the file will be on the classpath for subsequent work. So, the file you write using the XMIWriter; you specify the file to be called src-gen/something.ecore
Now, the problem is that the 'src-gen' will be part of some internal referneces in the ecore file. However, if you use it, since src-gen is part of the classpath, the file cannot be opened/used, since src-gen is wrong.
A solution for this problem is probably to distinguish between a base path and a file name in the XMIWriter.

bug.short_desc: Add support for UML 2.0 enumerations to OAW4.1 Classic

long_desc.thetext:
We would like to be able to use UML 2.0 enumerations in Classic mode. This probably requires changes to both the metamodel (Enumeration would be a subtype of Type, and would have an ordered collection of EnumerationLiterals) and the mapping file. Our application uses MagicDraw 11 and 11.5. This would enable a much cleaner use of enumerations for attributes than our present solution, which creates ad hoc stereotypes, e.g.,
myAttribute: String <<enumerated=ChoiceA!ChoiceB!ChoiceC>>
Real UML 2.0 enumerations could also be subclassed, something not possible with the above kludge.
TOBEFIXEDIN411

1) Many methods generated by the MMGenerators into the metaclasses are not really necessary, since the methods may be already available in superclasses. If possible, methods should only generated once in the baseclasses.
2) The generated classes can contain some Javadocs, especially some overview in the class header documentation. This would make it a lot easier to read the source code.

1) The MMGenerator templates have been reworked. Responsible for suppressing many methods is the extension "genSuperClass()", which returns true if the metaclass has a super-metaclass that is already generated. Methods that do not need to be redefined usually prove "genSuperClass()" to false to suppress redundant generation.
2) Class.xpt has now some documentation generation template code. In the class header documentation about - defined attributes - navigable associations to other metaclasses - configuration (isAbstract, isIncomplete, ...) is rendered. This makes it comfortable to read the Javadocs.
Also some methods have been documented.

bug.short_desc: [xpand] suppress blankline for template lines that do not produce code

long_desc.thetext:
�FOREACH something AS x� �IF condition� output �ENDIF� �ENDFOREACH�
In this example online the line containing "output" does produce useful code. The other lines contain only Xpand keywords, but anyway whitespaces and newlines are produced. The production of useless blank lines should be suppressed. This feature should be on as default, but maybe disabled by a keyword for DEFINE.
Why don't use the hyphen? i.e.: �FOREACH something AS x-� �IF condition-� output �ENDIF-� �ENDFOREACH-�

Reason is that we had to use too many hyphens and it is easy to forget them and they do not make the Xpand code readable. The customer has in the meanwhile tons of Xpand code and all they want to do is to completely suppress unneccessary blank lines. Another side effect in the project is that the Whitespace production consumes very measurable performance impacts, whereas skipping does perform well.
However, the automaticHyphens feature does not produce the wanted output, it suppresses too much.
The feature is realized in the meanwhile. It is possible to configure the new BlankLineSkippingOutput that does that job:
<component class="..." <output class="org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.output.BlankLineSkippingOutput"/>

Method org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.core.internal.builder.XpandResourceParser.parse(IFile, IOawResource) in oAW 4.1 instantiates Scanner with InputStream, which totally ignores file encoding. This leads to "unexpected char" OawBuilder errors for .xpt files with UTF-8 encoding, for example. It should wrap InputStream with InputStreamReader, with charset taken from IFile.getCharset().
